questions.question: Why do you want to work for this company?
questions.answer: Multiverse Computing caught my attention because you're leading the quantum computing revolution in Europe, and I'm fascinated by how AI can analyze DNA patterns and predict anomalies - that's what got me interested in Python originally. Your work with Singularity and CompactifAI represents exactly the kind of cutting-edge technology I want to support with my IT infrastructure skills. Working with your multicultural team while contributing to quantum and AI breakthroughs would be an incredible opportunity to grow my career in a field that's reshaping our world. I'm particularly excited about learning AWS and Fortinet in such an innovative environment.

questions.question: Where do you see yourself in five years?
questions.answer: In five years, I envision myself as a senior systems engineer at Multiverse Computing, specializing in Python automation and infrastructure optimization for quantum computing environments. I want to master the intersection of traditional IT systems and emerging technologies, building robust infrastructures that can handle the computational demands of your AI models. My goal is to become the go-to person for system reliability and automation, while also mentoring junior engineers. I see myself contributing to projects that push the boundaries of what's possible in quantum software.

questions.question: What are you looking for in your next role?
questions.answer: I'm seeking a role where I can combine my IT expertise with my growing Python skills in a company that's genuinely changing the world through technology. What attracts me to Multiverse Computing is the opportunity to work on infrastructure that supports quantum computing and AI compression - technologies I've been following since Python started gaining traction in predictive modeling. I want to be part of a team that values continuous learning, where I can grow from managing traditional servers to supporting revolutionary quantum applications. The chance to work in Spain with your international team adds an exciting personal dimension to this career move.

questions.question: Why did you leave your last job?
questions.answer: While I gained valuable experience managing point-of-sale systems and databases at Mundo Total, I realized I wanted to work on technology that has a broader impact on the world. My interest in Python and its applications in data analysis made me aware of how limited my growth opportunities were in traditional retail IT. When I discovered Multiverse Computing's work in quantum computing and AI, I knew this was the kind of environment where I could truly develop my technical skills. Your company offers the perfect blend of advanced technology, international exposure, and the chance to contribute to something genuinely innovative.

questions.question: What motivates you to do your best work?
questions.answer: I'm driven by the challenge of making complex systems work seamlessly, especially when they support groundbreaking technology like yours. There's something incredibly satisfying about optimizing a server configuration or writing a Python script that improves system efficiency - it's like solving a puzzle that has real-world impact. Working at Multiverse Computing would be particularly motivating because I'd be supporting technology that could revolutionize industries. The thought of contributing to quantum computing breakthroughs while developing my own skills in Python and advanced IT systems is exactly the kind of challenge that keeps me passionate about my work.

questions.question: What would you hope to achieve in the first six months after being hired?
questions.answer: In my first six months at Multiverse Computing, I'd focus on mastering your infrastructure while immediately contributing to system stability and security. I plan to thoroughly understand your SOPs and current Microsoft 365 and Linux configurations, then identify opportunities for Python-based automation improvements. By month three, I'd like to have implemented at least one automation script that improves our monitoring or maintenance processes. My goal is to become a reliable team member who not only maintains existing systems but also brings fresh ideas for optimization, particularly in areas where my Python skills can enhance traditional IT operations.

questions.question: Why will you be a good fit for this position?
questions.answer: My combination of hands-on IT experience and growing Python expertise makes me uniquely suited for Multiverse Computing's dynamic environment. Unlike many traditional IT professionals, I'm genuinely excited about the intersection of systems administration and emerging technologies - I've been following AI developments since Python started being used for DNA analysis. My experience with Linux servers, Active Directory, and network monitoring at MoDo Caracas directly translates to your infrastructure needs, while my self-taught Python projects show my commitment to continuous learning. Most importantly, I thrive in multicultural environments and am genuinely passionate about contributing to technology that matters.

questions.question: What excites you about this company?
questions.answer: What excites me most about Multiverse Computing is that you're not just another tech company - you're literally working on the future of computing and AI. The fact that you're the largest quantum software company in Europe while also being recognized as one of the most promising AI companies globally shows incredible ambition and capability. Your CompactifAI tool particularly interests me because model compression is such a critical challenge in AI deployment, and I'd love to support the infrastructure that makes this possible. The combination of quantum computing, AI innovation, and your commitment to ethics and sustainability creates exactly the kind of work environment where I can make a meaningful contribution.

questions.question: What is your biggest strength?
questions.answer: My biggest strength is my ability to bridge traditional IT operations with modern automation and programming approaches. While many system administrators stick to conventional methods, I actively seek ways to improve processes through Python scripting and automation. At MoDo Caracas, I didn't just implement Nagios - I customized it and created additional monitoring scripts that went beyond the standard setup. This combination of solid IT fundamentals with a programming mindset allows me to not only maintain systems but continuously improve them. It's exactly the kind of hybrid skill set that would be valuable in Multiverse Computing's innovative environment.

questions.question: What is your biggest weakness?
questions.answer: My biggest weakness has been my tendency to over-engineer solutions because I get excited about exploring new technical possibilities. Sometimes I spend extra time perfecting a Python script or system configuration when a simpler solution would work just fine. I've learned to balance this by setting clear time boundaries for tasks and consulting with colleagues about the appropriate level of complexity for each situation. While this trait can slow me down initially, it often results in more robust and maintainable solutions - which I believe would be valuable when working with Multiverse Computing's sophisticated technology stack.

questions.question: Explain a recent difficult project you worked on.
questions.answer: At MoDo Caracas, I led the implementation of a comprehensive monitoring solution using Nagios, which was challenging because we had a complex mix of legacy and modern systems. The difficulty wasn't just in the technical configuration, but in creating a monitoring strategy that would actually improve our response times without generating false alarms. I spent weeks analyzing our infrastructure patterns, writing custom Python scripts for specific monitoring tasks, and training the team on the new workflows. The project taught me that successful IT implementations require both technical expertise and change management skills - exactly the kind of holistic approach I'd bring to Multiverse Computing's infrastructure challenges.

questions.question: What is the most challenging aspect of your current project?
questions.answer: The most challenging aspect of my current work at MoDo Caracas is maintaining security while enabling innovation - we need systems that are both locked down and flexible enough for business growth. Balancing patch management, access controls, and system availability requires constant attention and often creative solutions. I've been developing Python scripts to automate security compliance checks while maintaining system performance, which has taught me to think like both a security professional and a system optimizer. This experience would be directly applicable at Multiverse Computing, where infrastructure security is critical for protecting intellectual property and client data.

questions.question: How do you stay up to date with the latest technologies?
questions.answer: I maintain my technical edge through a combination of hands-on projects and continuous learning that goes beyond my daily work requirements. I regularly build personal projects like my Next.js retail application and QR code generator to explore new frameworks and deployment strategies. I follow Python developments closely, particularly in areas like data analysis and automation, because I see these as the future of IT operations. Additionally, I stay current with industry trends through technical blogs, online courses, and experimenting with new tools in my home lab. This self-directed learning approach ensures I'm always ready to adopt new technologies like the AWS and Fortinet tools mentioned in your job requirements.

questions.question: What was the most fun thing you did recently?
questions.answer: Recently, I built a dynamic QR code management system using Next.js and MongoDB, which was incredibly fun because it combined several technologies I've been wanting to explore together. The project started as a simple idea but evolved into a full-featured application with user management, code tracking, and analytics - deployed on Vercel for real-world testing. What made it particularly enjoyable was solving the challenge of making QR codes that could be updated without changing the physical code itself. This kind of creative problem-solving and full-stack development is exactly what I love about technology, and it's the same enthusiasm I'd bring to infrastructure challenges at Multiverse Computing.

questions.question: What is broken around you?
questions.answer: At Mundo Total, I identified that our database backup process was a significant bottleneck - it was taking hours to complete and sometimes failing silently, putting our data at risk. The existing solution was a basic manual process that didn't scale with our growing data volumes or provide adequate verification. I developed a Python-based automation solution that not only reduced backup time by 70% but also included integrity checks and detailed logging. This experience taught me that the most critical problems are often the ones that seem to be working fine on the surface - you have to actively look for inefficiencies and potential failure points.

questions.question: What is the hardest technical problem you've faced?
questions.answer: The hardest technical problem I've encountered was a mysterious performance degradation at World Tel-Fax that affected our entire Contact Center operation during peak hours. The issue was intermittent, which made it incredibly difficult to diagnose - it would appear randomly and disappear before we could properly analyze it. I spent weeks correlating logs from multiple systems, writing monitoring scripts to capture data during these episodes, and eventually discovered it was caused by a complex interaction between our Asterisk phone system and database queries during high load. Solving this required not just technical skills but persistence and systematic thinking - qualities that would be essential when supporting Multiverse Computing's complex quantum and AI infrastructure.

questions.question: What do you know about this role and why does it interest you?
questions.answer: The IT Systems Engineer role at Multiverse Computing is fascinating because it's not just about maintaining traditional infrastructure - it's about supporting the computing environment for quantum software and AI model compression. From the job description, I understand you need someone who can manage everything from Microsoft 365 and Linux servers to network security and automation, which perfectly matches my experience. What particularly interests me is the opportunity to apply Python scripting and automation in an environment where system efficiency directly impacts breakthrough research. The role represents the perfect evolution of my career - taking my proven IT skills and applying them to support technology that's literally reshaping our understanding of computing.

questions.question: Take me through a product you launched from start to end.
questions.answer: I'll walk you through the GLPI service management system I implemented at MoDo Caracas, which transformed how we handled IT support requests. The project began when I noticed we were losing track of issues and had no visibility into response times or recurring problems. I started by researching solutions, chose GLPI for its flexibility, and spent two weeks configuring it to match our workflows and integrating it with our existing systems. The implementation phase involved migrating historical data, training the entire IT team, and gradually rolling it out to end users with extensive documentation and support. Six months after launch, we had reduced average resolution time by 40% and gained complete visibility into our IT operations - exactly the kind of systematic improvement I'd bring to Multiverse Computing.

questions.question: What's your biggest achievement in previous projects?
questions.answer: My biggest achievement was the comprehensive monitoring system I implemented at MoDo Caracas using Nagios, which fundamentally changed how we managed our IT infrastructure. Beyond just installing the software, I created custom monitoring scripts in Python that tracked business-critical metrics specific to our environment, reducing unplanned downtime by over 60%. The system I built didn't just monitor - it provided predictive insights that allowed us to prevent issues before they affected users. What made this achievement special was that it required me to think beyond traditional IT support and develop a more strategic, proactive approach to infrastructure management - exactly the mindset needed for supporting Multiverse Computing's advanced technology stack.

questions.question: Tell me about a recent failure and what you learned.
questions.answer: At Mundo Total, I underestimated the complexity of integrating a new point-of-sale system with existing fiscal printers, which led to a day-long outage that affected store operations. I had focused too much on the technical configuration and didn't adequately test the integration under real-world conditions with actual transaction volumes. The failure taught me that successful IT implementations require not just technical knowledge but thorough testing scenarios that simulate actual business operations. I now approach every project with a more comprehensive testing strategy and always include stakeholders in the validation process. This experience made me a more cautious and thorough engineer, which would be crucial when working with Multiverse Computing's mission-critical quantum and AI systems.

category: Cultura y Alineación con la Empresa

questions.question: What do you know about our company's mission?
questions.answer: Multiverse Computing's mission is to democratize access to quantum computing and make AI more efficient through innovative software solutions like Singularity and CompactifAI. What resonates with me is that you're not just developing technology for technology's sake - you're solving real problems for companies in finance, energy, and manufacturing while maintaining a strong ethical foundation. Your work in AI model compression particularly interests me because it addresses one of the biggest practical challenges in AI deployment today. I see my role as IT Systems Engineer as directly supporting this mission by ensuring the infrastructure is reliable, secure, and optimized for the groundbreaking work your research and development teams are doing.

questions.question: How do you align with our company values?
questions.answer: Multiverse Computing's values of innovation, ethics, and diversity align perfectly with my personal and professional approach to technology work. Your commitment to sustainability and ethical AI development reflects my own belief that technology should improve the world, not just generate profit. I've always thrived in multicultural environments - even in Venezuela, I worked with diverse teams and learned to appreciate different perspectives on problem-solving. Your emphasis on continuous learning and growth matches my self-directed approach to skill development, from my Python projects to my exploration of new IT automation techniques. I believe that diverse teams create better solutions, and I'm excited to contribute my Latin American perspective to your international team.

questions.question: What kind of company culture do you thrive in?
questions.answer: I thrive in cultures that combine intellectual curiosity with practical problem-solving - exactly what I see at Multiverse Computing. I do my best work in environments where learning is encouraged and where technical challenges are seen as opportunities for growth rather than just problems to solve. Your culture of collaboration and innovation appeals to me because I've always been someone who enjoys sharing knowledge and learning from colleagues with different expertise. The fact that Multiverse Computing is working on technology that genuinely matters - quantum computing and AI optimization - creates the kind of purposeful work environment where I can be genuinely passionate about contributing to something bigger than myself.

questions.question: Why do you think you'd fit in here?
questions.answer: I'd fit in at Multiverse Computing because I share your passion for using technology to solve meaningful problems, and I have the technical skills to contribute immediately while continuing to grow. My experience with complex IT infrastructure management would directly support your quantum and AI research, while my self-taught Python skills show the kind of continuous learning mindset that thrives in your environment. What sets me apart is my genuine excitement about the intersection of traditional IT operations and cutting-edge technology - I'm not just looking for any job, I'm specifically drawn to the unique challenges of supporting quantum computing infrastructure. Plus, my multicultural background and adaptability would fit well with your international team dynamic.

questions.question: What's important to you in a workplace?
questions.answer: The most important thing to me in a workplace is the opportunity to work on technology that has genuine impact while continuously developing my skills alongside brilliant colleagues. I want to be in an environment where asking questions is encouraged and where my contributions can make a real difference in advancing important work. Multiverse Computing offers exactly this - the chance to support quantum computing and AI research while working with world-leading experts in a truly international setting. I also value ethical leadership and companies that consider the broader implications of their technology, which clearly aligns with your approach to AI development and your commitment to sustainability and diversity.

questions.question: How do you contribute to a positive team culture?
questions.answer: I contribute to positive team culture by being the person who bridges technical knowledge gaps and helps colleagues succeed with their projects. At MoDo Caracas, I was known for patiently explaining complex systems to non-technical staff and always being willing to help troubleshoot problems outside my direct responsibilities. I believe in documentation and knowledge sharing - when I implement something new, I make sure the entire team understands it and can maintain it. My approach is to be helpful without being condescending, and to bring creative solutions to team challenges. I think my Latin American background also brings a different cultural perspective that can enrich team dynamics and problem-solving approaches.

questions.question: Describe a time you went above and beyond for a team.
questions.answer: During a critical server migration at World Tel-Fax, our Contact Center was at risk of extended downtime during peak business hours. Even though the migration wasn't originally my responsibility, I volunteered to work through the weekend to develop a backup failover system that would minimize service interruption. I spent my own time researching and testing solutions, then coordinated with multiple teams to implement a strategy that reduced the planned downtime from 8 hours to less than 2 hours. The experience taught me that going above and beyond isn't just about working extra hours - it's about taking ownership of outcomes and finding creative solutions that benefit the entire organization. This is exactly the kind of commitment I'd bring to supporting Multiverse Computing's critical infrastructure.

questions.question: What do you do to stay motivated in a team setting?
questions.answer: I stay motivated in team settings by focusing on how my technical contributions enable my colleagues to do their best work - there's nothing more satisfying than solving an infrastructure problem that unblocks someone's research or development work. I actively seek out opportunities to learn from teammates with different expertise, which keeps me engaged and helps me see how my IT skills fit into the bigger picture. At Multiverse Computing, I'd be particularly motivated by the knowledge that the systems I maintain and optimize directly support breakthrough research in quantum computing and AI. Working alongside world-leading experts while contributing to technology that could change industries would provide incredible daily motivation.

questions.question: How do you handle a team with diverse perspectives?
questions.answer: I handle diverse teams by listening actively and recognizing that different backgrounds often lead to better solutions than any individual perspective alone. In my experience at World Tel-Fax working with colleagues from different departments and technical backgrounds, I learned that the key is to focus on common goals while respecting different approaches to achieving them. I make an effort to understand not just what someone is suggesting, but why they're suggesting it based on their experience and expertise. At Multiverse Computing, I'd bring this same openness to working with colleagues from different countries and technical specializations, knowing that the intersection of diverse perspectives is often where the most innovative solutions emerge.

questions.question: What makes you excited about our company's future?
questions.answer: What excites me most about Multiverse Computing's future is that you're positioned at the intersection of two of the most transformative technologies of our time - quantum computing and artificial intelligence. Your growth from a 2019 startup to Europe's largest quantum software company shows incredible momentum, and your recognition as one of the top 100 AI companies globally indicates you're just getting started. The practical applications of CompactifAI for making AI more efficient and accessible could democratize AI deployment across industries, while Singularity continues to solve real problems for major companies. Being part of this journey, supporting the infrastructure that enables these breakthroughs, would be the opportunity of a lifetime - I'd be contributing to technology that future generations will look back on as foundational to our digital transformation.

questions.question: Tell me about a time you met a tight deadline.
questions.answer: When MoDo Caracas needed to upgrade our entire Microsoft 365 environment over a single weekend to avoid business disruption, I had less than 48 hours to plan and execute a complex migration. The challenge wasn't just technical - I had to coordinate with multiple departments, prepare rollback procedures, and ensure zero data loss during the transition. I spent Friday night creating detailed runbooks and testing procedures, then worked through Saturday implementing the upgrade while continuously monitoring system performance. By Sunday evening, we had successfully migrated over 200 users with zero downtime and actually improved system performance. The experience taught me that meeting tight deadlines requires both technical expertise and exceptional planning skills.

questions.question: What was the most difficult bug you fixed recently?
questions.answer: At Mundo Total, I encountered a bizarre issue where our point-of-sale system would randomly lose connection to fiscal printers, but only during specific transaction types and only on certain days of the week. The bug was incredibly difficult to reproduce and seemed to have no logical pattern, which made traditional debugging approaches ineffective. I spent weeks creating monitoring scripts to capture system state during these failures, analyzing network traffic patterns, and eventually discovered it was related to a memory leak that occurred when processing certain tax calculations under high load conditions. Solving this required patience, systematic data collection, and the creativity to look beyond obvious causes - skills that would be valuable when troubleshooting complex issues in Multiverse Computing's sophisticated technology environment.

questions.question: How do you tackle challenges?
questions.answer: My approach to challenges is methodical but flexible - I start by gathering all available information to understand the scope and root cause, then develop multiple potential solutions before choosing the best approach. I believe in documenting everything throughout the process, both for accountability and to help future troubleshooting efforts. When I implemented the Nagios monitoring system at MoDo Caracas, I faced the challenge of monitoring diverse systems with different requirements, so I broke it down into phases: assessment, proof of concept, gradual rollout, and optimization. This systematic approach ensures I don't miss critical details while maintaining momentum toward a solution. For complex challenges like those at Multiverse Computing, this methodical yet adaptable approach would be essential.

questions.question: Describe a difficult challenge you faced and how you overcame it.
questions.answer: At World Tel-Fax, our entire Contact Center infrastructure started experiencing intermittent failures that were affecting customer service operations, but the problems were so sporadic that traditional monitoring couldn't identify the cause. The challenge was compounded by the fact that the system supported critical business operations that couldn't be taken offline for extensive testing. I developed a comprehensive logging and monitoring strategy using Python scripts to capture detailed system state information during normal and problematic periods, then analyzed this data to identify patterns. After three weeks of detective work, I discovered the issue was caused by a complex interaction between our Asterisk phone system and database queries during peak loads. The solution required both technical innovation and patience - exactly the kind of persistent problem-solving approach needed for supporting Multiverse Computing's complex infrastructure.

questions.question: Tell me about a time you had to persevere for months.
questions.answer: The GLPI implementation at MoDo Caracas took over six months from conception to full deployment, requiring sustained effort and continuous problem-solving throughout the process. The challenge wasn't just technical - I had to gradually change how the entire IT team approached service management while maintaining daily operations. There were weeks when the project seemed to stall due to user resistance or technical complications, but I maintained momentum by celebrating small wins and continuously demonstrating value to stakeholders. The key was breaking the large project into manageable phases while keeping the end goal in sight and adapting the approach based on feedback and changing requirements. This experience taught me that successful long-term projects require both technical skills and the ability to manage change over extended periods.

questions.question: What's the most constructive feedback you've received?
questions.answer: A senior engineer at MoDo Caracas once told me that while my technical solutions were solid, I needed to improve my communication about project progress and potential risks to non-technical stakeholders. He pointed out that my detailed technical explanations sometimes confused rather than informed management, and that I should focus more on business impact and timelines. I took this feedback seriously and started preparing separate technical and executive summaries for my projects, learning to translate technical concepts into business language. This feedback fundamentally improved my effectiveness as an IT professional and helped me understand that technical excellence must be paired with clear communication to create real business value - a skill that would be crucial when working with Multiverse Computing's diverse stakeholders.

questions.question: Tell me about a time you had to deliver bad news.
questions.answer: When the database backup system at MoDo Caracas failed and we discovered that our previous three weeks of backups were corrupted, I had to inform management that we had a significant data vulnerability during a critical business period. Rather than just reporting the problem, I came prepared with a immediate recovery plan, a timeline for implementing better backup verification procedures, and a post-mortem analysis of how the failure occurred. I focused on being transparent about the risks while demonstrating that I had a clear path to resolution and prevention. The key was taking responsibility for the oversight while showing proactive leadership in solving the problem. Management appreciated the honesty and comprehensive response, which actually strengthened their confidence in my ability to handle critical infrastructure issues.

questions.question: What aspects of your work are most often criticized?
questions.answer: I've been told that I sometimes spend too much time perfecting technical solutions when a simpler approach would be adequate for the immediate need. My tendency to explore all possible optimizations and edge cases can slow down project delivery, especially when working under tight deadlines. At Mundo Total, my manager pointed out that while my thorough approach produced robust solutions, it wasn't always the most efficient use of time for routine tasks. I've learned to better assess when perfectionism adds value versus when it's simply perfectionism for its own sake. Now I explicitly ask stakeholders about their priorities for each project - do they need the quick solution or the comprehensive solution? This self-awareness would be valuable at Multiverse Computing, where I'd need to balance thoroughness with the fast pace of innovation.

questions.question: How do you handle criticism of your work?
questions.answer: When I receive criticism, I try to separate my emotional reaction from the technical content and focus on what I can learn to improve my work and approach. At World Tel-Fax, a colleague criticized my network monitoring setup for generating too many false alarms, which initially felt like an attack on my technical skills. However, I realized they were right - effective monitoring should reduce noise, not increase it. I worked with them to understand their workflow and refined the alert thresholds to provide more actionable information. This experience taught me that criticism often comes from people who have to work with my solutions daily, and their feedback is invaluable for creating truly effective systems. At Multiverse Computing, I'd actively seek this kind of practical feedback to ensure my infrastructure solutions truly serve the team's needs.

questions.question: What is something you had to push for in a project?
questions.answer: At MoDo Caracas, I had to advocate strongly for implementing proper change management procedures because the team was resistant to what they saw as bureaucratic overhead that would slow down their work. I understood their concern - nobody wants unnecessary paperwork - but I knew from experience that undocumented changes were causing recurring issues and making troubleshooting much more difficult. Rather than just mandating the procedures, I developed a streamlined change tracking system using Python scripts that automated much of the documentation and actually made their work easier by providing better visibility into system modifications. The key was showing them that good process could enhance rather than hinder their effectiveness. This experience taught me that pushing for improvements requires not just conviction but the ability to design solutions that address real concerns while achieving the desired outcome.
